1.-1: Enter Theseus, Hippolyta, Philostrate and Attendants.

1.speaker: THESEUS.
1.line: Now, fair Hippolyta, our nuptial hour

2.speaker: THESEUS.
2.line: Draws on apace; four happy days bring in

3.speaker: THESEUS.
3.line: Another moon; but oh, methinks, how slow

4.speaker: THESEUS.
4.line: This old moon wanes! She lingers my desires,

5.speaker: THESEUS.
5.line: Like to a step-dame or a dowager,

6.speaker: THESEUS.
6.line: Long withering out a young man’s revenue.

7.speaker: HIPPOLYTA.
7.line: Four days will quickly steep themselves in night;

8.speaker: HIPPOLYTA.
8.line: Four nights will quickly dream away the time;

9.speaker: HIPPOLYTA.
9.line: And then the moon, like to a silver bow

10.speaker: HIPPOLYTA.
10.line: New bent in heaven, shall behold the night

13.speaker: THESEUS.
13.line: Stir up the Athenian youth to merriments;

14.speaker: THESEUS.
14.line: Awake the pert and nimble spirit of mirth;

16.speaker: THESEUS.
16.line: The pale companion is not for our pomp.

17.speaker: THESEUS.
17.line: Hippolyta, I woo’d thee with my sword,

18.speaker: THESEUS.
18.line: And won thy love doing thee injuries;

19.speaker: THESEUS.
19.line: But I will wed thee in another key,

20.speaker: THESEUS.
20.line: With pomp, with triumph, and with revelling.

1.-3: Enter Egeus, Hermia, Lysander and Demetrius.

21.speaker: EGEUS.
21.line: Happy be Theseus, our renownèd Duke!

22.speaker: THESEUS.
22.line: Thanks, good Egeus. What’s the news with thee?

23.speaker: EGEUS.
23.line: Full of vexation come I, with complaint

24.speaker: EGEUS.
24.line: Against my child, my daughter Hermia.

25.speaker: EGEUS.
25.line: Stand forth, Demetrius. My noble lord,

26.speaker: EGEUS.
26.line: This man hath my consent to marry her.

27.speaker: EGEUS.
27.line: Stand forth, Lysander. And, my gracious Duke,

28.speaker: EGEUS.
28.line: This man hath bewitch’d the bosom of my child.

29.speaker: EGEUS.
29.line: Thou, thou, Lysander, thou hast given her rhymes,

30.speaker: EGEUS.
30.line: And interchang’d love-tokens with my child.

31.speaker: EGEUS.
31.line: Thou hast by moonlight at her window sung,

32.speaker: EGEUS.
32.line: With feigning voice, verses of feigning love;

33.speaker: EGEUS.
33.line: And stol’n the impression of her fantasy

34.speaker: EGEUS.
34.line: With bracelets of thy hair, rings, gauds, conceits,

36.speaker: EGEUS.
36.line: Of strong prevailment in unharden’d youth)

37.speaker: EGEUS.
37.line: With cunning hast thou filch’d my daughter’s heart,

38.speaker: EGEUS.
38.line: Turn’d her obedience (which is due to me)

39.speaker: EGEUS.
39.line: To stubborn harshness. And, my gracious Duke,

40.speaker: EGEUS.
40.line: Be it so she will not here before your grace

42.speaker: EGEUS.
42.line: I beg the ancient privilege of Athens:

43.speaker: EGEUS.
43.line: As she is mine I may dispose of her;

44.speaker: EGEUS.
44.line: Which shall be either to this gentleman

45.speaker: EGEUS.
45.line: Or to her death, according to our law

47.speaker: THESEUS.
47.line: What say you, Hermia? Be advis’d, fair maid.

48.speaker: THESEUS.
48.line: To you your father should be as a god;

49.speaker: THESEUS.
49.line: One that compos’d your beauties, yea, and one

50.speaker: THESEUS.
50.line: To whom you are but as a form in wax

51.speaker: THESEUS.
51.line: By him imprinted, and within his power

52.speaker: THESEUS.
52.line: To leave the figure, or disfigure it.

56.speaker: THESEUS.
56.line: But in this kind, wanting your father’s voice,

57.speaker: THESEUS.
57.line: The other must be held the worthier.

58.speaker: HERMIA.
58.line: I would my father look’d but with my eyes.

59.speaker: THESEUS.
59.line: Rather your eyes must with his judgment look.

60.speaker: HERMIA.
60.line: I do entreat your Grace to pardon me.

61.speaker: HERMIA.
61.line: I know not by what power I am made bold,

62.speaker: HERMIA.
62.line: Nor how it may concern my modesty

63.speaker: HERMIA.
63.line: In such a presence here to plead my thoughts:

64.speaker: HERMIA.
64.line: But I beseech your Grace that I may know

65.speaker: HERMIA.
65.line: The worst that may befall me in this case,

66.speaker: HERMIA.
66.line: If I refuse to wed Demetrius.

67.speaker: THESEUS.
67.line: Either to die the death, or to abjure

68.speaker: THESEUS.
68.line: For ever the society of men.

69.speaker: THESEUS.
69.line: Therefore, fair Hermia, question your desires,

70.speaker: THESEUS.
70.line: Know of your youth, examine well your blood,

71.speaker: THESEUS.
71.line: Whether, if you yield not to your father’s choice,

72.speaker: THESEUS.
72.line: You can endure the livery of a nun,

73.speaker: THESEUS.
73.line: For aye to be in shady cloister mew’d,

74.speaker: THESEUS.
74.line: To live a barren sister all your life,

75.speaker: THESEUS.
75.line: Chanting faint hymns to the cold fruitless moon.

76.speaker: THESEUS.
76.line: Thrice-blessèd they that master so their blood

78.speaker: THESEUS.
78.line: But earthlier happy is the rose distill’d

79.speaker: THESEUS.
79.line: Than that which, withering on the virgin thorn,

80.speaker: THESEUS.
80.line: Grows, lives, and dies, in single blessedness.

81.speaker: HERMIA.
81.line: So will I grow, so live, so die, my lord,

82.speaker: HERMIA.
82.line: Ere I will yield my virgin patent up

83.speaker: HERMIA.
83.line: Unto his lordship, whose unwishèd yoke

84.speaker: HERMIA.
84.line: My soul consents not to give sovereignty.

85.speaker: THESEUS.
85.line: Take time to pause; and by the next new moon

86.speaker: THESEUS.
86.line: The sealing-day betwixt my love and me

88.speaker: THESEUS.
88.line: Upon that day either prepare to die

89.speaker: THESEUS.
89.line: For disobedience to your father’s will,

90.speaker: THESEUS.
90.line: Or else to wed Demetrius, as he would,

91.speaker: THESEUS.
91.line: Or on Diana’s altar to protest

92.speaker: THESEUS.
92.line: For aye austerity and single life.

93.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
93.line: Relent, sweet Hermia; and, Lysander, yield

94.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
94.line: Thy crazèd title to my certain right.

95.speaker: LYSANDER.
95.line: You have her father’s love, Demetrius.

96.speaker: LYSANDER.
96.line: Let me have Hermia’s. Do you marry him.

97.speaker: EGEUS.
97.line: Scornful Lysander, true, he hath my love;

98.speaker: EGEUS.
98.line: And what is mine my love shall render him;

99.speaker: EGEUS.
99.line: And she is mine, and all my right of her

101.speaker: LYSANDER.
101.line: I am, my lord, as well deriv’d as he,

102.speaker: LYSANDER.
102.line: As well possess’d; my love is more than his;

103.speaker: LYSANDER.
103.line: My fortunes every way as fairly rank’d,

104.speaker: LYSANDER.
104.line: If not with vantage, as Demetrius’;

105.speaker: LYSANDER.
105.line: And, which is more than all these boasts can be,

106.speaker: LYSANDER.
106.line: I am belov’d of beauteous Hermia.

107.speaker: LYSANDER.
107.line: Why should not I then prosecute my right?

108.speaker: LYSANDER.
108.line: Demetrius, I’ll avouch it to his head,

109.speaker: LYSANDER.
109.line: Made love to Nedar’s daughter, Helena,

110.speaker: LYSANDER.
110.line: And won her soul; and she, sweet lady, dotes,

112.speaker: LYSANDER.
112.line: Upon this spotted and inconstant man.

113.speaker: THESEUS.
113.line: I must confess that I have heard so much,

114.speaker: THESEUS.
114.line: And with Demetrius thought to have spoke thereof;

116.speaker: THESEUS.
116.line: My mind did lose it.—But, Demetrius, come,

117.speaker: THESEUS.
117.line: And come, Egeus; you shall go with me.

118.speaker: THESEUS.
118.line: I have some private schooling for you both.—

119.speaker: THESEUS.
119.line: For you, fair Hermia, look you arm yourself

120.speaker: THESEUS.
120.line: To fit your fancies to your father’s will,

121.speaker: THESEUS.
121.line: Or else the law of Athens yields you up

122.speaker: THESEUS.
122.line: (Which by no means we may extenuate)

123.speaker: THESEUS.
123.line: To death, or to a vow of single life.

124.speaker: THESEUS.
124.line: Come, my Hippolyta. What cheer, my love?

126.speaker: THESEUS.
126.line: I must employ you in some business

127.speaker: THESEUS.
127.line: Against our nuptial, and confer with you

128.speaker: THESEUS.
128.line: Of something nearly that concerns yourselves.

129.speaker: EGEUS.
129.line: With duty and desire we follow you.

130.speaker: LYSANDER.
130.line: How now, my love? Why is your cheek so pale?

131.speaker: LYSANDER.
131.line: How chance the roses there do fade so fast?

132.speaker: HERMIA.
132.line: Belike for want of rain, which I could well

133.speaker: HERMIA.
133.line: Beteem them from the tempest of my eyes.

134.speaker: LYSANDER.
134.line: Ay me! For aught that I could ever read,

135.speaker: LYSANDER.
135.line: Could ever hear by tale or history,

136.speaker: LYSANDER.
136.line: The course of true love never did run smooth.

137.speaker: LYSANDER.
137.line: But either it was different in blood—

138.speaker: HERMIA.
138.line: O cross! Too high to be enthrall’d to low.

139.speaker: LYSANDER.
139.line: Or else misgraffèd in respect of years—

140.speaker: HERMIA.
140.line: O spite! Too old to be engag’d to young.

141.speaker: LYSANDER.
141.line: Or else it stood upon the choice of friends—

142.speaker: HERMIA.
142.line: O hell! to choose love by another’s eyes!

143.speaker: LYSANDER.
143.line: Or, if there were a sympathy in choice,

144.speaker: LYSANDER.
144.line: War, death, or sickness did lay siege to it,

145.speaker: LYSANDER.
145.line: Making it momentany as a sound,

146.speaker: LYSANDER.
146.line: Swift as a shadow, short as any dream,

147.speaker: LYSANDER.
147.line: Brief as the lightning in the collied night

148.speaker: LYSANDER.
148.line: That, in a spleen, unfolds both heaven and earth,

149.speaker: LYSANDER.
149.line: And, ere a man hath power to say, ‘Behold!’

150.speaker: LYSANDER.
150.line: The jaws of darkness do devour it up:

151.speaker: LYSANDER.
151.line: So quick bright things come to confusion.

152.speaker: HERMIA.
152.line: If then true lovers have ever cross’d,

153.speaker: HERMIA.
153.line: It stands as an edict in destiny.

154.speaker: HERMIA.
154.line: Then let us teach our trial patience,

155.speaker: HERMIA.
155.line: Because it is a customary cross,

156.speaker: HERMIA.
156.line: As due to love as thoughts and dreams and sighs,

157.speaker: HERMIA.
157.line: Wishes and tears, poor fancy’s followers.

158.speaker: LYSANDER.
158.line: A good persuasion; therefore, hear me, Hermia.

159.speaker: LYSANDER.
159.line: I have a widow aunt, a dowager

160.speaker: LYSANDER.
160.line: Of great revenue, and she hath no child.

161.speaker: LYSANDER.
161.line: From Athens is her house remote seven leagues,

162.speaker: LYSANDER.
162.line: And she respects me as her only son.

163.speaker: LYSANDER.
163.line: There, gentle Hermia, may I marry thee,

164.speaker: LYSANDER.
164.line: And to that place the sharp Athenian law

165.speaker: LYSANDER.
165.line: Cannot pursue us. If thou lovest me then,

166.speaker: LYSANDER.
166.line: Steal forth thy father’s house tomorrow night;

167.speaker: LYSANDER.
167.line: And in the wood, a league without the town

168.speaker: LYSANDER.
168.line: (Where I did meet thee once with Helena

169.speaker: LYSANDER.
169.line: To do observance to a morn of May),

170.speaker: LYSANDER.
170.line: There will I stay for thee.

172.speaker: HERMIA.
172.line: I swear to thee by Cupid’s strongest bow,

173.speaker: HERMIA.
173.line: By his best arrow with the golden head,

174.speaker: HERMIA.
174.line: By the simplicity of Venus’ doves,

175.speaker: HERMIA.
175.line: By that which knitteth souls and prospers loves,

176.speaker: HERMIA.
176.line: And by that fire which burn’d the Carthage queen

177.speaker: HERMIA.
177.line: When the false Trojan under sail was seen,

178.speaker: HERMIA.
178.line: By all the vows that ever men have broke

179.speaker: HERMIA.
179.line: (In number more than ever women spoke),

180.speaker: HERMIA.
180.line: In that same place thou hast appointed me,

181.speaker: HERMIA.
181.line: Tomorrow truly will I meet with thee.

182.speaker: LYSANDER.
182.line: Keep promise, love. Look, here comes Helena.

183.speaker: HERMIA.
183.line: God speed fair Helena! Whither away?

184.speaker: HELENA.
184.line: Call you me fair? That fair again unsay.

185.speaker: HELENA.
185.line: Demetrius loves your fair. O happy fair!

186.speaker: HELENA.
186.line: Your eyes are lode-stars and your tongue’s sweet air

187.speaker: HELENA.
187.line: More tuneable than lark to shepherd’s ear,

188.speaker: HELENA.
188.line: When wheat is green, when hawthorn buds appear.

189.speaker: HELENA.
189.line: Sickness is catching. O were favour so,

190.speaker: HELENA.
190.line: Yours would I catch, fair Hermia, ere I go.

191.speaker: HELENA.
191.line: My ear should catch your voice, my eye your eye,

192.speaker: HELENA.
192.line: My tongue should catch your tongue’s sweet melody.

193.speaker: HELENA.
193.line: Were the world mine, Demetrius being bated,

194.speaker: HELENA.
194.line: The rest I’d give to be to you translated.

195.speaker: HELENA.
195.line: O, teach me how you look, and with what art

196.speaker: HELENA.
196.line: You sway the motion of Demetrius’ heart!

197.speaker: HERMIA.
197.line: I frown upon him, yet he loves me still.

198.speaker: HELENA.
198.line: O that your frowns would teach my smiles such skill!

199.speaker: HERMIA.
199.line: I give him curses, yet he gives me love.

200.speaker: HELENA.
200.line: O that my prayers could such affection move!

201.speaker: HERMIA.
201.line: The more I hate, the more he follows me.

202.speaker: HELENA.
202.line: The more I love, the more he hateth me.

203.speaker: HERMIA.
203.line: His folly, Helena, is no fault of mine.

204.speaker: HELENA.
204.line: None but your beauty; would that fault were mine!

205.speaker: HERMIA.
205.line: Take comfort: he no more shall see my face;

206.speaker: HERMIA.
206.line: Lysander and myself will fly this place.

207.speaker: HERMIA.
207.line: Before the time I did Lysander see,

208.speaker: HERMIA.
208.line: Seem’d Athens as a paradise to me.

209.speaker: HERMIA.
209.line: O, then, what graces in my love do dwell,

210.speaker: HERMIA.
210.line: That he hath turn’d a heaven into hell!

211.speaker: LYSANDER.
211.line: Helen, to you our minds we will unfold:

212.speaker: LYSANDER.
212.line: Tomorrow night, when Phoebe doth behold

213.speaker: LYSANDER.
213.line: Her silver visage in the watery glass,

214.speaker: LYSANDER.
214.line: Decking with liquid pearl the bladed grass

215.speaker: LYSANDER.
215.line: (A time that lovers’ flights doth still conceal),

216.speaker: LYSANDER.
216.line: Through Athens’ gates have we devis’d to steal.

217.speaker: HERMIA.
217.line: And in the wood where often you and I

218.speaker: HERMIA.
218.line: Upon faint primrose beds were wont to lie,

219.speaker: HERMIA.
219.line: Emptying our bosoms of their counsel sweet,

220.speaker: HERMIA.
220.line: There my Lysander and myself shall meet,

221.speaker: HERMIA.
221.line: And thence from Athens turn away our eyes,

222.speaker: HERMIA.
222.line: To seek new friends and stranger companies.

223.speaker: HERMIA.
223.line: Farewell, sweet playfellow. Pray thou for us,

224.speaker: HERMIA.
224.line: And good luck grant thee thy Demetrius!

225.speaker: HERMIA.
225.line: Keep word, Lysander. We must starve our sight

226.speaker: HERMIA.
226.line: From lovers’ food, till morrow deep midnight.

229.speaker: LYSANDER.
229.line: As you on him, Demetrius dote on you!

230.speaker: HELENA.
230.line: How happy some o’er other some can be!

231.speaker: HELENA.
231.line: Through Athens I am thought as fair as she.

232.speaker: HELENA.
232.line: But what of that? Demetrius thinks not so;

233.speaker: HELENA.
233.line: He will not know what all but he do know.

234.speaker: HELENA.
234.line: And as he errs, doting on Hermia’s eyes,

235.speaker: HELENA.
235.line: So I, admiring of his qualities.

236.speaker: HELENA.
236.line: Things base and vile, holding no quantity,

237.speaker: HELENA.
237.line: Love can transpose to form and dignity.

238.speaker: HELENA.
238.line: Love looks not with the eyes, but with the mind;

239.speaker: HELENA.
239.line: And therefore is wing’d Cupid painted blind.

240.speaker: HELENA.
240.line: Nor hath love’s mind of any judgment taste.

241.speaker: HELENA.
241.line: Wings, and no eyes, figure unheedy haste.

242.speaker: HELENA.
242.line: And therefore is love said to be a child,

243.speaker: HELENA.
243.line: Because in choice he is so oft beguil’d.

244.speaker: HELENA.
244.line: As waggish boys in game themselves forswear,

245.speaker: HELENA.
245.line: So the boy Love is perjur’d everywhere.

246.speaker: HELENA.
246.line: For, ere Demetrius look’d on Hermia’s eyne,

247.speaker: HELENA.
247.line: He hail’d down oaths that he was only mine;

248.speaker: HELENA.
248.line: And when this hail some heat from Hermia felt,

249.speaker: HELENA.
249.line: So he dissolv’d, and showers of oaths did melt.

250.speaker: HELENA.
250.line: I will go tell him of fair Hermia’s flight.

251.speaker: HELENA.
251.line: Then to the wood will he tomorrow night

252.speaker: HELENA.
252.line: Pursue her; and for this intelligence

253.speaker: HELENA.
253.line: If I have thanks, it is a dear expense.

254.speaker: HELENA.
254.line: But herein mean I to enrich my pain,

255.speaker: HELENA.
255.line: To have his sight thither and back again.

2.-1: Enter Quince, Snug, Bottom, Flute, Snout  and Starveling.

2.speaker: BOTTOM.
2.line: You were best to call them generally, man by man, according to the

4.speaker: QUINCE.
4.line: Here is the scroll of every man’s name, which is thought fit through

5.speaker: QUINCE.
5.line: all Athens, to play in our interlude before the Duke and Duchess, on

7.speaker: BOTTOM.
7.line: First, good Peter Quince, say what the play treats on; then read the

8.speaker: BOTTOM.
8.line: names of the actors; and so grow to a point.

9.speaker: QUINCE.
9.line: Marry, our play is _The most lamentable comedy and most cruel death of

11.speaker: BOTTOM.
11.line: A very good piece of work, I assure you, and a merry. Now, good Peter

12.speaker: BOTTOM.
12.line: Quince, call forth your actors by the scroll. Masters, spread

14.speaker: QUINCE.
14.line: Answer, as I call you. Nick Bottom, the weaver.

15.speaker: BOTTOM.
15.line: Ready. Name what part I am for, and proceed.

16.speaker: QUINCE.
16.line: You, Nick Bottom, are set down for Pyramus.

17.speaker: BOTTOM.
17.line: What is Pyramus—a lover, or a tyrant?

18.speaker: QUINCE.
18.line: A lover, that kills himself most gallantly for love.

19.speaker: BOTTOM.
19.line: That will ask some tears in the true performing of it. If I do it, let

20.speaker: BOTTOM.
20.line: the audience look to their eyes. I will move storms; I will condole in

21.speaker: BOTTOM.
21.line: some measure. To the rest—yet my chief humour is for a tyrant. I could

22.speaker: BOTTOM.
22.line: play Ercles rarely, or a part to tear a cat in, to make all split.

31.speaker: BOTTOM.
31.line: This was lofty. Now name the rest of the players. This is Ercles’ vein,

32.speaker: BOTTOM.
32.line: a tyrant’s vein; a lover is more condoling.

35.speaker: QUINCE.
35.line: Flute, you must take Thisbe on you.

36.speaker: FLUTE.
36.line: What is Thisbe? A wandering knight?

37.speaker: QUINCE.
37.line: It is the lady that Pyramus must love.

38.speaker: FLUTE.
38.line: Nay, faith, let not me play a woman. I have a beard coming.

39.speaker: QUINCE.
39.line: That’s all one. You shall play it in a mask, and you may speak as small

41.speaker: BOTTOM.
41.line: And I may hide my face, let me play Thisbe too. I’ll speak in a

42.speaker: BOTTOM.
42.line: monstrous little voice; ‘Thisne, Thisne!’—‘Ah, Pyramus, my lover dear!

43.speaker: BOTTOM.
43.line: thy Thisbe dear! and lady dear!’

44.speaker: QUINCE.
44.line: No, no, you must play Pyramus; and, Flute, you Thisbe.

48.speaker: QUINCE.
48.line: Robin Starveling, you must play Thisbe’s mother.

51.speaker: QUINCE.
51.line: You, Pyramus’ father; myself, Thisbe’s father;

52.speaker: QUINCE.
52.line: Snug, the joiner, you, the lion’s part. And, I hope here is a play

54.speaker: SNUG
54.line: Have you the lion’s part written? Pray you, if it be, give it me, for I

56.speaker: QUINCE.
56.line: You may do it extempore, for it is nothing but roaring.

57.speaker: BOTTOM.
57.line: Let me play the lion too. I will roar that I will do any man’s heart

58.speaker: BOTTOM.
58.line: good to hear me. I will roar that I will make the Duke say ‘Let him

59.speaker: BOTTOM.
59.line: roar again, let him roar again.’

60.speaker: QUINCE.
60.line: If you should do it too terribly, you would fright the Duchess and the

61.speaker: QUINCE.
61.line: ladies, that they would shriek; and that were enough to hang us all.

62.speaker: ALL
62.line: That would hang us every mother’s son.

63.speaker: BOTTOM.
63.line: I grant you, friends, if you should fright the ladies out of their

64.speaker: BOTTOM.
64.line: wits, they would have no more discretion but to hang us. But I will

65.speaker: BOTTOM.
65.line: aggravate my voice so, that I will roar you as gently as any sucking

66.speaker: BOTTOM.
66.line: dove; I will roar you an ’twere any nightingale.

67.speaker: QUINCE.
67.line: You can play no part but Pyramus, for Pyramus is a sweet-faced man; a

68.speaker: QUINCE.
68.line: proper man as one shall see in a summer’s day; a most lovely

69.speaker: QUINCE.
69.line: gentleman-like man. Therefore you must needs play Pyramus.

70.speaker: BOTTOM.
70.line: Well, I will undertake it. What beard were I best to play it in?

72.speaker: BOTTOM.
72.line: I will discharge it in either your straw-colour beard, your

73.speaker: BOTTOM.
73.line: orange-tawny beard, your purple-in-grain beard, or your

75.speaker: QUINCE.
75.line: Some of your French crowns have no hair at all, and then you will play

76.speaker: QUINCE.
76.line: bare-faced. But, masters, here are your parts, and I am to entreat you,

77.speaker: QUINCE.
77.line: request you, and desire you, to con them by tomorrow night; and meet me

78.speaker: QUINCE.
78.line: in the palace wood, a mile without the town, by moonlight; there will

79.speaker: QUINCE.
79.line: we rehearse, for if we meet in the city, we shall be dogg’d with

80.speaker: QUINCE.
80.line: company, and our devices known. In the meantime I will draw a bill of

81.speaker: QUINCE.
81.line: properties, such as our play wants. I pray you fail me not.

82.speaker: BOTTOM.
82.line: We will meet, and there we may rehearse most obscenely and

83.speaker: BOTTOM.
83.line: courageously. Take pains, be perfect; adieu.

84.speaker: QUINCE.
84.line: At the Duke’s oak we meet.

1.-1: Enter a Fairy at one door, and Puck at another.

1.speaker: PUCK.
1.line: How now, spirit! Whither wander you?

8.speaker: FAIRY
8.line: And I serve the Fairy Queen,

9.speaker: FAIRY
9.line: To dew her orbs upon the green.

10.speaker: FAIRY
10.line: The cowslips tall her pensioners be,

11.speaker: FAIRY
11.line: In their gold coats spots you see;

13.speaker: FAIRY
13.line: In those freckles live their savours.

14.speaker: FAIRY
14.line: I must go seek some dew-drops here,

15.speaker: FAIRY
15.line: And hang a pearl in every cowslip’s ear.

16.speaker: FAIRY
16.line: Farewell, thou lob of spirits; I’ll be gone.

17.speaker: FAIRY
17.line: Our Queen and all her elves come here anon.

18.speaker: PUCK.
18.line: The King doth keep his revels here tonight;

19.speaker: PUCK.
19.line: Take heed the Queen come not within his sight,

20.speaker: PUCK.
20.line: For Oberon is passing fell and wrath,

21.speaker: PUCK.
21.line: Because that she, as her attendant, hath

22.speaker: PUCK.
22.line: A lovely boy, stol’n from an Indian king;

23.speaker: PUCK.
23.line: She never had so sweet a changeling.

24.speaker: PUCK.
24.line: And jealous Oberon would have the child

25.speaker: PUCK.
25.line: Knight of his train, to trace the forests wild:

26.speaker: PUCK.
26.line: But she perforce withholds the lovèd boy,

27.speaker: PUCK.
27.line: Crowns him with flowers, and makes him all her joy.

28.speaker: PUCK.
28.line: And now they never meet in grove or green,

29.speaker: PUCK.
29.line: By fountain clear, or spangled starlight sheen,

30.speaker: PUCK.
30.line: But they do square; that all their elves for fear

31.speaker: PUCK.
31.line: Creep into acorn cups, and hide them there.

32.speaker: FAIRY
32.line: Either I mistake your shape and making quite,

33.speaker: FAIRY
33.line: Or else you are that shrewd and knavish sprite

34.speaker: FAIRY
34.line: Call’d Robin Goodfellow. Are not you he

35.speaker: FAIRY
35.line: That frights the maidens of the villagery,

36.speaker: FAIRY
36.line: Skim milk, and sometimes labour in the quern,

37.speaker: FAIRY
37.line: And bootless make the breathless housewife churn,

38.speaker: FAIRY
38.line: And sometime make the drink to bear no barm,

39.speaker: FAIRY
39.line: Mislead night-wanderers, laughing at their harm?

40.speaker: FAIRY
40.line: Those that Hobgoblin call you, and sweet Puck,

41.speaker: FAIRY
41.line: You do their work, and they shall have good luck.

44.speaker: PUCK.
44.line: I am that merry wanderer of the night.

45.speaker: PUCK.
45.line: I jest to Oberon, and make him smile,

46.speaker: PUCK.
46.line: When I a fat and bean-fed horse beguile,

47.speaker: PUCK.
47.line: Neighing in likeness of a filly foal;

48.speaker: PUCK.
48.line: And sometime lurk I in a gossip’s bowl

49.speaker: PUCK.
49.line: In very likeness of a roasted crab,

50.speaker: PUCK.
50.line: And, when she drinks, against her lips I bob,

51.speaker: PUCK.
51.line: And on her withered dewlap pour the ale.

52.speaker: PUCK.
52.line: The wisest aunt, telling the saddest tale,

53.speaker: PUCK.
53.line: Sometime for three-foot stool mistaketh me;

54.speaker: PUCK.
54.line: Then slip I from her bum, down topples she,

55.speaker: PUCK.
55.line: And ‘tailor’ cries, and falls into a cough;

56.speaker: PUCK.
56.line: And then the whole quire hold their hips and loffe

57.speaker: PUCK.
57.line: And waxen in their mirth, and neeze, and swear

58.speaker: PUCK.
58.line: A merrier hour was never wasted there.

59.speaker: PUCK.
59.line: But room, fairy. Here comes Oberon.

60.speaker: FAIRY
60.line: And here my mistress. Would that he were gone!

84.speaker: TITANIA.
84.line: And never, since the middle summer’s spring,

86.speaker: TITANIA.
86.line: By pavèd fountain, or by rushy brook,

90.speaker: TITANIA.
90.line: Therefore the winds, piping to us in vain,

91.speaker: TITANIA.
91.line: As in revenge, have suck’d up from the sea

92.speaker: TITANIA.
92.line: Contagious fogs; which, falling in the land,

95.line: The ox hath therefore stretch’d his yoke in vain,

99.speaker: TITANIA.

102.speaker: TITANIA.

104.speaker: TITANIA.

105.speaker: TITANIA.
105.line: Therefore the moon, the governess of floods,

110.speaker: TITANIA.

111.speaker: TITANIA.

112.speaker: TITANIA.

113.speaker: TITANIA.

117.speaker: TITANIA.
117.line: And this same progeny of evils comes

118.speaker: TITANIA.

119.speaker: TITANIA.

120.speaker: OBERON.
120.line: Do you amend it, then. It lies in you.

121.line: Why should Titania cross her Oberon?

122.speaker: OBERON.
122.line: I do but beg a little changeling boy

125.line: The fairyland buys not the child of me.

126.speaker: TITANIA.
126.line: His mother was a vot’ress of my order,

127.speaker: TITANIA.
127.line: And in the spicèd Indian air, by night,

128.speaker: TITANIA.
128.line: Full often hath she gossip’d by my side;

129.speaker: TITANIA.
129.line: And sat with me on Neptune’s yellow sands,

130.speaker: TITANIA.

131.speaker: TITANIA.
131.line: When we have laugh’d to see the sails conceive,

132.speaker: TITANIA.
132.line: And grow big-bellied with the wanton wind;

133.speaker: TITANIA.

134.speaker: TITANIA.

135.speaker: TITANIA.
135.line: Would imitate, and sail upon the land,

136.speaker: TITANIA.
136.line: To fetch me trifles, and return again,

137.speaker: TITANIA.
137.line: As from a voyage, rich with merchandise.

138.speaker: TITANIA.
138.line: But she, being mortal, of that boy did die;

139.speaker: TITANIA.
139.line: And for her sake do I rear up her boy,

140.speaker: TITANIA.

141.line: How long within this wood intend you stay?

143.speaker: TITANIA.
143.line: If you will patiently dance in our round,

144.speaker: TITANIA.

146.speaker: OBERON.
146.line: Give me that boy and I will go with thee.

147.speaker: TITANIA.

148.speaker: TITANIA.

149.speaker: OBERON.

150.speaker: OBERON.

151.speaker: OBERON.
151.line: My gentle Puck, come hither. Thou rememb’rest

152.line: Since once I sat upon a promontory,

153.speaker: OBERON.

193.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
193.line: I love thee not, therefore pursue me not.

194.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
194.line: Where is Lysander and fair Hermia?

195.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
195.line: The one I’ll slay, the other slayeth me.

196.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
196.line: Thou told’st me they were stol’n into this wood,

197.line: And here am I, and wode within this wood

199.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
199.line: Hence, get thee gone, and follow me no more.

200.speaker: HELENA.
200.line: You draw me, you hard-hearted adamant,

201.speaker: HELENA.
201.line: But yet you draw not iron, for my heart

202.speaker: HELENA.
202.line: Is true as steel. Leave you your power to draw,

203.speaker: HELENA.
203.line: And I shall have no power to follow you.

204.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
204.line: Do I entice you? Do I speak you fair?

205.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
205.line: Or rather do I not in plainest truth

206.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
206.line: Tell you I do not, nor I cannot love you?

207.speaker: HELENA.
207.line: And even for that do I love you the more.

208.speaker: HELENA.
208.line: I am your spaniel; and, Demetrius,

209.speaker: HELENA.
209.line: The more you beat me, I will fawn on you.

210.speaker: HELENA.
210.line: Use me but as your spaniel, spurn me, strike me,

211.speaker: HELENA.
211.line: Neglect me, lose me; only give me leave,

212.speaker: HELENA.
212.line: Unworthy as I am, to follow you.

213.speaker: HELENA.
213.line: What worser place can I beg in your love,

214.speaker: HELENA.
214.line: (And yet a place of high respect with me)

215.speaker: HELENA.
215.line: Than to be usèd as you use your dog?

216.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
216.line: Tempt not too much the hatred of my spirit;

217.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
217.line: For I am sick when I do look on thee.

218.speaker: HELENA.
218.line: And I am sick when I look not on you.

219.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
219.line: You do impeach your modesty too much

220.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
220.line: To leave the city and commit yourself

221.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
221.line: Into the hands of one that loves you not,

222.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
222.line: To trust the opportunity of night

223.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
223.line: And the ill counsel of a desert place,

224.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
224.line: With the rich worth of your virginity.

225.speaker: HELENA.
225.line: Your virtue is my privilege: for that

226.speaker: HELENA.
226.line: It is not night when I do see your face,

227.speaker: HELENA.
227.line: Therefore I think I am not in the night;

228.speaker: HELENA.
228.line: Nor doth this wood lack worlds of company,

229.speaker: HELENA.
229.line: For you, in my respect, are all the world.

230.speaker: HELENA.
230.line: Then how can it be said I am alone

231.speaker: HELENA.
231.line: When all the world is here to look on me?

232.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
232.line: I’ll run from thee and hide me in the brakes,

233.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
233.line: And leave thee to the mercy of wild beasts.

234.speaker: HELENA.
234.line: The wildest hath not such a heart as you.

235.speaker: HELENA.
235.line: Run when you will, the story shall be chang’d;

236.speaker: HELENA.

237.speaker: HELENA.
237.line: The dove pursues the griffin, the mild hind

238.line: Makes speed to catch the tiger. Bootless speed,

239.speaker: HELENA.
239.line: When cowardice pursues and valour flies!

240.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
240.line: I will not stay thy questions. Let me go,

241.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
241.line: Or if thou follow me, do not believe

242.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
242.line: But I shall do thee mischief in the wood.

243.speaker: HELENA.
243.line: Ay, in the temple, in the town, the field,

244.speaker: HELENA.
244.line: You do me mischief. Fie, Demetrius!

245.speaker: HELENA.
245.line: Your wrongs do set a scandal on my sex.

246.speaker: HELENA.
246.line: We cannot fight for love as men may do.

247.speaker: HELENA.
247.line: We should be woo’d, and were not made to woo.

248.speaker: HELENA.
248.line: I’ll follow thee, and make a heaven of hell,

249.speaker: HELENA.
249.line: To die upon the hand I love so well.

250.speaker: OBERON.
250.line: Fare thee well, nymph. Ere he do leave this grove,

251.speaker: OBERON.
251.line: Thou shalt fly him, and he shall seek thy love.

252.speaker: OBERON.
252.line: Hast thou the flower there? Welcome, wanderer.

254.speaker: OBERON.
254.line: I pray thee give it me.

255.speaker: OBERON.
255.line: I know a bank where the wild thyme blows,

256.speaker: OBERON.
256.line: Where oxlips and the nodding violet grows,

258.speaker: OBERON.
258.line: With sweet musk-roses, and with eglantine.

259.speaker: OBERON.
259.line: There sleeps Titania sometime of the night,

260.speaker: OBERON.
260.line: Lull’d in these flowers with dances and delight;

261.speaker: OBERON.
261.line: And there the snake throws her enamell’d skin,

262.speaker: OBERON.
262.line: Weed wide enough to wrap a fairy in.

263.speaker: OBERON.
263.line: And with the juice of this I’ll streak her eyes,

264.speaker: OBERON.
264.line: And make her full of hateful fantasies.

265.speaker: OBERON.
265.line: Take thou some of it, and seek through this grove:

266.speaker: OBERON.
266.line: A sweet Athenian lady is in love

267.speaker: OBERON.
267.line: With a disdainful youth. Anoint his eyes;

268.speaker: OBERON.
268.line: But do it when the next thing he espies

271.speaker: OBERON.
271.line: Effect it with some care, that he may prove

272.speaker: OBERON.

273.speaker: OBERON.

18.speaker: PUCK.
18.line: Anon, his Thisbe must be answerèd,

19.speaker: PUCK.
19.line: And forth my mimic comes. When they him spy,

20.speaker: PUCK.
20.line: As wild geese that the creeping fowler eye,

21.speaker: PUCK.
21.line: Or russet-pated choughs, many in sort,

22.speaker: PUCK.
22.line: Rising and cawing at the gun’s report,

23.speaker: PUCK.
23.line: Sever themselves and madly sweep the sky,

24.speaker: PUCK.
24.line: So at his sight away his fellows fly,

25.speaker: PUCK.
25.line: And at our stamp, here o’er and o’er one falls;

26.speaker: PUCK.
26.line: He murder cries, and help from Athens calls.

27.speaker: PUCK.
27.line: Their sense thus weak, lost with their fears, thus strong,

28.speaker: PUCK.
28.line: Made senseless things begin to do them wrong;

29.speaker: PUCK.
29.line: For briers and thorns at their apparel snatch;

30.speaker: PUCK.
30.line: Some sleeves, some hats, from yielders all things catch.

31.speaker: PUCK.
31.line: I led them on in this distracted fear,

32.speaker: PUCK.
32.line: And left sweet Pyramus translated there.

33.speaker: PUCK.
33.line: When in that moment, so it came to pass,

34.speaker: PUCK.
34.line: Titania wak’d, and straightway lov’d an ass.

35.speaker: OBERON.
35.line: This falls out better than I could devise.

36.speaker: OBERON.
36.line: But hast thou yet latch’d the Athenian’s eyes

37.speaker: OBERON.
37.line: With the love-juice, as I did bid thee do?

38.speaker: PUCK.
38.line: I took him sleeping—that is finish’d too—

39.speaker: PUCK.
39.line: And the Athenian woman by his side,

40.speaker: PUCK.
40.line: That, when he wak’d, of force she must be ey’d.

41.speaker: OBERON.
41.line: Stand close. This is the same Athenian.

42.speaker: PUCK.
42.line: This is the woman, but not this the man.

43.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
43.line: O why rebuke you him that loves you so?

44.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
44.line: Lay breath so bitter on your bitter foe.

45.speaker: HERMIA.
45.line: Now I but chide, but I should use thee worse,

46.speaker: HERMIA.
46.line: For thou, I fear, hast given me cause to curse.

47.speaker: HERMIA.
47.line: If thou hast slain Lysander in his sleep,

48.speaker: HERMIA.
48.line: Being o’er shoes in blood, plunge in the deep,

50.speaker: HERMIA.
50.line: The sun was not so true unto the day

51.speaker: HERMIA.
51.line: As he to me. Would he have stol’n away

52.speaker: HERMIA.
52.line: From sleeping Hermia? I’ll believe as soon

53.speaker: HERMIA.
53.line: This whole earth may be bor’d, and that the moon

54.speaker: HERMIA.
54.line: May through the centre creep and so displease

55.speaker: HERMIA.
55.line: Her brother’s noontide with th’ Antipodes.

56.speaker: HERMIA.
56.line: It cannot be but thou hast murder’d him.

57.speaker: HERMIA.
57.line: So should a murderer look, so dead, so grim.

58.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
58.line: So should the murder’d look, and so should I,

59.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
59.line: Pierc’d through the heart with your stern cruelty.

60.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
60.line: Yet you, the murderer, look as bright, as clear,

61.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
61.line: As yonder Venus in her glimmering sphere.

62.speaker: HERMIA.
62.line: What’s this to my Lysander? Where is he?

63.speaker: HERMIA.
63.line: Ah, good Demetrius, wilt thou give him me?

64.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
64.line: I had rather give his carcass to my hounds.

65.speaker: HERMIA.
65.line: Out, dog! Out, cur! Thou driv’st me past the bounds

66.speaker: HERMIA.
66.line: Of maiden’s patience. Hast thou slain him, then?

67.speaker: HERMIA.
67.line: Henceforth be never number’d among men!

68.speaker: HERMIA.
68.line: O once tell true; tell true, even for my sake!

69.speaker: HERMIA.
69.line: Durst thou have look’d upon him, being awake,

70.speaker: HERMIA.
70.line: And hast thou kill’d him sleeping? O brave touch!

71.speaker: HERMIA.
71.line: Could not a worm, an adder, do so much?

72.speaker: HERMIA.
72.line: An adder did it; for with doubler tongue

73.speaker: HERMIA.
73.line: Than thine, thou serpent, never adder stung.

74.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
74.line: You spend your passion on a mispris’d mood:

75.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
75.line: I am not guilty of Lysander’s blood;

76.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
76.line: Nor is he dead, for aught that I can tell.

77.speaker: HERMIA.
77.line: I pray thee, tell me then that he is well.

78.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
78.line: And if I could, what should I get therefore?

79.speaker: HERMIA.
79.line: A privilege never to see me more.

80.speaker: HERMIA.
80.line: And from thy hated presence part I so:

81.speaker: HERMIA.
81.line: See me no more, whether he be dead or no.

82.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
82.line: There is no following her in this fierce vein.

83.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
83.line: Here, therefore, for a while I will remain.

84.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
84.line: So sorrow’s heaviness doth heavier grow

85.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
85.line: For debt that bankrupt sleep doth sorrow owe;

86.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
86.line: Which now in some slight measure it will pay,

87.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
87.line: If for his tender here I make some stay.

88.speaker: OBERON.
88.line: What hast thou done? Thou hast mistaken quite,

89.speaker: OBERON.
89.line: And laid the love-juice on some true-love’s sight.

90.speaker: OBERON.
90.line: Of thy misprision must perforce ensue

91.speaker: OBERON.
91.line: Some true love turn’d, and not a false turn’d true.

92.speaker: PUCK.
92.line: Then fate o’er-rules, that, one man holding troth,

93.speaker: PUCK.
93.line: A million fail, confounding oath on oath.

94.speaker: OBERON.
94.line: About the wood go swifter than the wind,

95.speaker: OBERON.
95.line: And Helena of Athens look thou find.

96.speaker: OBERON.
96.line: All fancy-sick she is, and pale of cheer

97.speaker: OBERON.
97.line: With sighs of love, that costs the fresh blood dear.

98.speaker: OBERON.
98.line: By some illusion see thou bring her here;

99.speaker: OBERON.
99.line: I’ll charm his eyes against she do appear.

100.speaker: PUCK.
100.line: I go, I go; look how I go,

101.speaker: PUCK.
101.line: Swifter than arrow from the Tartar’s bow.

104.speaker: OBERON.
104.line: Sink in apple of his eye.

105.speaker: OBERON.
105.line: When his love he doth espy,

107.speaker: OBERON.
107.line: As the Venus of the sky.—

108.speaker: OBERON.
108.line: When thou wak’st, if she be by,

112.speaker: PUCK.
112.line: And the youth mistook by me,

114.speaker: PUCK.
114.line: Shall we their fond pageant see?

115.speaker: PUCK.
115.line: Lord, what fools these mortals be!

116.speaker: OBERON.
116.line: Stand aside. The noise they make

118.speaker: PUCK.
118.line: Then will two at once woo one.

119.speaker: PUCK.
119.line: That must needs be sport alone;

120.speaker: PUCK.
120.line: And those things do best please me

122.speaker: LYSANDER.
122.line: Why should you think that I should woo in scorn?

123.speaker: LYSANDER.
123.line: Scorn and derision never come in tears.

124.speaker: LYSANDER.
124.line: Look when I vow, I weep; and vows so born,

125.speaker: LYSANDER.
125.line: In their nativity all truth appears.

126.speaker: LYSANDER.
126.line: How can these things in me seem scorn to you,

127.speaker: LYSANDER.
127.line: Bearing the badge of faith, to prove them true?

128.speaker: HELENA.
128.line: You do advance your cunning more and more.

129.speaker: HELENA.
129.line: When truth kills truth, O devilish-holy fray!

130.speaker: HELENA.
130.line: These vows are Hermia’s: will you give her o’er?

131.speaker: HELENA.
131.line: Weigh oath with oath, and you will nothing weigh:

132.speaker: HELENA.
132.line: Your vows to her and me, put in two scales,

133.speaker: HELENA.
133.line: Will even weigh; and both as light as tales.

134.speaker: LYSANDER.
134.line: I had no judgment when to her I swore.

135.speaker: HELENA.
135.line: Nor none, in my mind, now you give her o’er.

136.speaker: LYSANDER.
136.line: Demetrius loves her, and he loves not you.

137.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
137.line: [_Waking._] O Helen, goddess, nymph, perfect, divine!

138.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
138.line: To what, my love, shall I compare thine eyne?

139.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
139.line: Crystal is muddy. O how ripe in show

140.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
140.line: Thy lips, those kissing cherries, tempting grow!

141.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
141.line: That pure congealèd white, high Taurus’ snow,

142.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
142.line: Fann’d with the eastern wind, turns to a crow

143.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
143.line: When thou hold’st up thy hand. O, let me kiss

144.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
144.line: This princess of pure white, this seal of bliss!

145.speaker: HELENA.
145.line: O spite! O hell! I see you all are bent

146.speaker: HELENA.
146.line: To set against me for your merriment.

147.speaker: HELENA.
147.line: If you were civil, and knew courtesy,

148.speaker: HELENA.
148.line: You would not do me thus much injury.

149.speaker: HELENA.
149.line: Can you not hate me, as I know you do,

150.speaker: HELENA.
150.line: But you must join in souls to mock me too?

151.speaker: HELENA.
151.line: If you were men, as men you are in show,

152.speaker: HELENA.
152.line: You would not use a gentle lady so;

153.speaker: HELENA.
153.line: To vow, and swear, and superpraise my parts,

154.speaker: HELENA.
154.line: When I am sure you hate me with your hearts.

155.speaker: HELENA.
155.line: You both are rivals, and love Hermia;

156.speaker: HELENA.
156.line: And now both rivals, to mock Helena.

157.speaker: HELENA.
157.line: A trim exploit, a manly enterprise,

158.speaker: HELENA.
158.line: To conjure tears up in a poor maid’s eyes

159.speaker: HELENA.
159.line: With your derision! None of noble sort

160.speaker: HELENA.
160.line: Would so offend a virgin, and extort

161.speaker: HELENA.
161.line: A poor soul’s patience, all to make you sport.

162.speaker: LYSANDER.
162.line: You are unkind, Demetrius; be not so,

163.speaker: LYSANDER.
163.line: For you love Hermia; this you know I know.

164.speaker: LYSANDER.
164.line: And here, with all good will, with all my heart,

165.speaker: LYSANDER.
165.line: In Hermia’s love I yield you up my part;

166.speaker: LYSANDER.
166.line: And yours of Helena to me bequeath,

167.speaker: LYSANDER.
167.line: Whom I do love and will do till my death.

168.speaker: HELENA.
168.line: Never did mockers waste more idle breath.

169.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
169.line: Lysander, keep thy Hermia; I will none.

170.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
170.line: If e’er I lov’d her, all that love is gone.

171.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
171.line: My heart to her but as guest-wise sojourn’d;

172.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
172.line: And now to Helen is it home return’d,

175.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
175.line: Disparage not the faith thou dost not know,

176.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
176.line: Lest to thy peril thou aby it dear.

177.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
177.line: Look where thy love comes; yonder is thy dear.

178.speaker: HERMIA.
178.line: Dark night, that from the eye his function takes,

179.speaker: HERMIA.
179.line: The ear more quick of apprehension makes;

180.speaker: HERMIA.
180.line: Wherein it doth impair the seeing sense,

181.speaker: HERMIA.
181.line: It pays the hearing double recompense.

182.speaker: HERMIA.
182.line: Thou art not by mine eye, Lysander, found;

183.speaker: HERMIA.
183.line: Mine ear, I thank it, brought me to thy sound.

184.speaker: HERMIA.
184.line: But why unkindly didst thou leave me so?

185.speaker: LYSANDER.
185.line: Why should he stay whom love doth press to go?

186.speaker: HERMIA.
186.line: What love could press Lysander from my side?

187.speaker: LYSANDER.
187.line: Lysander’s love, that would not let him bide,

188.speaker: LYSANDER.
188.line: Fair Helena, who more engilds the night

189.speaker: LYSANDER.
189.line: Than all yon fiery oes and eyes of light.

190.speaker: LYSANDER.
190.line: Why seek’st thou me? Could not this make thee know

191.speaker: LYSANDER.
191.line: The hate I bare thee made me leave thee so?

192.speaker: HERMIA.
192.line: You speak not as you think; it cannot be.

193.speaker: HELENA.
193.line: Lo, she is one of this confederacy!

194.speaker: HELENA.
194.line: Now I perceive they have conjoin’d all three

195.speaker: HELENA.
195.line: To fashion this false sport in spite of me.

197.speaker: HELENA.
197.line: Have you conspir’d, have you with these contriv’d,

198.speaker: HELENA.
198.line: To bait me with this foul derision?

199.speaker: HELENA.
199.line: Is all the counsel that we two have shar’d,

200.speaker: HELENA.
200.line: The sisters’ vows, the hours that we have spent,

201.speaker: HELENA.
201.line: When we have chid the hasty-footed time

202.speaker: HELENA.
202.line: For parting us—O, is all forgot?

204.speaker: HELENA.
204.line: We, Hermia, like two artificial gods,

205.speaker: HELENA.
205.line: Have with our needles created both one flower,

206.speaker: HELENA.
206.line: Both on one sampler, sitting on one cushion,

207.speaker: HELENA.
207.line: Both warbling of one song, both in one key,

208.speaker: HELENA.
208.line: As if our hands, our sides, voices, and minds,

209.speaker: HELENA.
209.line: Had been incorporate. So we grew together,

210.speaker: HELENA.
210.line: Like to a double cherry, seeming parted,

211.speaker: HELENA.
211.line: But yet a union in partition,

212.speaker: HELENA.
212.line: Two lovely berries moulded on one stem;

213.speaker: HELENA.
213.line: So, with two seeming bodies, but one heart;

214.speaker: HELENA.
214.line: Two of the first, like coats in heraldry,

215.speaker: HELENA.
215.line: Due but to one, and crownèd with one crest.

216.speaker: HELENA.
216.line: And will you rent our ancient love asunder,

217.speaker: HELENA.
217.line: To join with men in scorning your poor friend?

218.speaker: HELENA.
218.line: It is not friendly, ’tis not maidenly.

219.speaker: HELENA.
219.line: Our sex, as well as I, may chide you for it,

220.speaker: HELENA.
220.line: Though I alone do feel the injury.

221.speaker: HERMIA.
221.line: I am amazèd at your passionate words:

222.speaker: HERMIA.
222.line: I scorn you not; it seems that you scorn me.

223.speaker: HELENA.
223.line: Have you not set Lysander, as in scorn,

224.speaker: HELENA.
224.line: To follow me, and praise my eyes and face?

225.speaker: HELENA.
225.line: And made your other love, Demetrius,

226.speaker: HELENA.
226.line: Who even but now did spurn me with his foot,

227.speaker: HELENA.
227.line: To call me goddess, nymph, divine and rare,

228.speaker: HELENA.
228.line: Precious, celestial? Wherefore speaks he this

229.speaker: HELENA.
229.line: To her he hates? And wherefore doth Lysander

230.speaker: HELENA.
230.line: Deny your love, so rich within his soul,

232.speaker: HELENA.
232.line: But by your setting on, by your consent?

233.speaker: HELENA.
233.line: What though I be not so in grace as you,

234.speaker: HELENA.
234.line: So hung upon with love, so fortunate,

235.speaker: HELENA.
235.line: But miserable most, to love unlov’d?

236.speaker: HELENA.
236.line: This you should pity rather than despise.

237.speaker: HERMIA.
237.line: I understand not what you mean by this.

238.speaker: HELENA.
238.line: Ay, do. Persever, counterfeit sad looks,

239.speaker: HELENA.
239.line: Make mouths upon me when I turn my back,

240.speaker: HELENA.
240.line: Wink each at other; hold the sweet jest up.

241.speaker: HELENA.
241.line: This sport, well carried, shall be chronicled.

242.speaker: HELENA.
242.line: If you have any pity, grace, or manners,

243.speaker: HELENA.
243.line: You would not make me such an argument.

244.speaker: HELENA.
244.line: But fare ye well. ’Tis partly my own fault,

245.speaker: HELENA.
245.line: Which death, or absence, soon shall remedy.

246.speaker: LYSANDER.
246.line: Stay, gentle Helena; hear my excuse;

247.speaker: LYSANDER.
247.line: My love, my life, my soul, fair Helena!

249.speaker: HERMIA.
249.line: Sweet, do not scorn her so.

250.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
250.line: If she cannot entreat, I can compel.

251.speaker: LYSANDER.
251.line: Thou canst compel no more than she entreat;

252.speaker: LYSANDER.
252.line: Thy threats have no more strength than her weak prayers.

253.speaker: LYSANDER.
253.line: Helen, I love thee, by my life I do;

254.speaker: LYSANDER.
254.line: I swear by that which I will lose for thee

255.speaker: LYSANDER.
255.line: To prove him false that says I love thee not.

256.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
256.line: I say I love thee more than he can do.

257.speaker: LYSANDER.
257.line: If thou say so, withdraw, and prove it too.

262.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
262.line: Seem to break loose. Take on as you would follow,

263.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
263.line: But yet come not. You are a tame man, go!

264.speaker: LYSANDER.
264.line: Hang off, thou cat, thou burr! Vile thing, let loose,

265.speaker: LYSANDER.
265.line: Or I will shake thee from me like a serpent.

266.speaker: HERMIA.
266.line: Why are you grown so rude? What change is this,

268.speaker: LYSANDER.
268.line: Thy love? Out, tawny Tartar, out!

269.speaker: LYSANDER.
269.line: Out, loathèd medicine! O hated potion, hence!

271.speaker: HELENA.
271.line: Yes, sooth, and so do you.

272.speaker: LYSANDER.
272.line: Demetrius, I will keep my word with thee.

273.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
273.line: I would I had your bond; for I perceive

274.speaker: DEMETRIUS.
274.line: A weak bond holds you; I’ll not trust your word.

275.speaker: LYSANDER.
275.line: What, should I hurt her, strike her, kill her dead?

276.speaker: LYSANDER.
276.line: Although I hate her, I’ll not harm her so.

277.speaker: HERMIA.
277.line: What, can you do me greater harm than hate?

278.speaker: HERMIA.
278.line: Hate me? Wherefore? O me! what news, my love?

279.speaker: HERMIA.
279.line: Am not I Hermia? Are not you Lysander?

280.speaker: HERMIA.
280.line: I am as fair now as I was erewhile.

281.speaker: HERMIA.
281.line: Since night you lov’d me; yet since night you left me.

282.speaker: HERMIA.
282.line: Why then, you left me—O, the gods forbid!—

285.speaker: LYSANDER.
285.line: And never did desire to see thee more.

286.speaker: LYSANDER.
286.line: Therefore be out of hope, of question, of doubt;

287.speaker: LYSANDER.
287.line: Be certain, nothing truer; ’tis no jest

288.speaker: LYSANDER.
288.line: That I do hate thee and love Helena.

289.speaker: HERMIA.
289.line: O me! You juggler! You cankerblossom!

290.speaker: HERMIA.
290.line: You thief of love! What! have you come by night

291.speaker: HERMIA.
291.line: And stol’n my love’s heart from him?

293.speaker: HELENA.
293.line: Have you no modesty, no maiden shame,

294.speaker: HELENA.
294.line: No touch of bashfulness? What, will you tear

295.speaker: HELENA.
295.line: Impatient answers from my gentle tongue?

296.speaker: HELENA.
296.line: Fie, fie, you counterfeit, you puppet, you!

297.speaker: HERMIA.
297.line: Puppet! Why so? Ay, that way goes the game.

298.speaker: HERMIA.
298.line: Now I perceive that she hath made compare

299.speaker: HERMIA.
299.line: Between our statures; she hath urg’d her height;

300.speaker: HERMIA.
300.line: And with her personage, her tall personage,

301.speaker: HERMIA.
301.line: Her height, forsooth, she hath prevail’d with him.

302.speaker: HERMIA.
302.line: And are you grown so high in his esteem

303.speaker: HERMIA.
303.line: Because I am so dwarfish and so low?

304.speaker: HERMIA.
304.line: How low am I, thou painted maypole? Speak,

305.speaker: HERMIA.
305.line: How low am I? I am not yet so low

306.speaker: HERMIA.
306.line: But that my nails can reach unto thine eyes.

307.speaker: HELENA.
307.line: I pray you, though you mock me, gentlemen,

308.speaker: HELENA.
308.line: Let her not hurt me. I was never curst;

309.speaker: HELENA.
309.line: I have no gift at all in shrewishness;

310.speaker: HELENA.
310.line: I am a right maid for my cowardice;

311.speaker: HELENA.
311.line: Let her not strike me. You perhaps may think,

312.speaker: HELENA.
312.line: Because she is something lower than myself,

315.speaker: HELENA.
315.line: Good Hermia, do not be so bitter with me.

316.speaker: HELENA.
316.line: I evermore did love you, Hermia,

317.speaker: HELENA.
317.line: Did ever keep your counsels, never wrong’d you,

318.speaker: HELENA.
318.line: Save that, in love unto Demetrius,

319.speaker: HELENA.
319.line: I told him of your stealth unto this wood.

320.speaker: HELENA.
320.line: He follow’d you; for love I follow’d him;

321.speaker: HELENA.
321.line: But he hath chid me hence, and threaten’d me

322.speaker: HELENA.
322.line: To strike me, spurn me, nay, to kill me too:

323.speaker: HELENA.
323.line: And now, so you will let me quiet go,

324.speaker: HELENA.
324.line: To Athens will I bear my folly back,

325.speaker: HELENA.
325.line: And follow you no further. Let me go:

326.speaker: HELENA.
326.line: You see how simple and how fond I am.

327.speaker: HERMIA.
327.line: Why, get you gone. Who is’t that hinders you?

328.speaker: HELENA.
328.line: A foolish heart that I leave here behind.

331.speaker: LYSANDER.
331.line: Be not afraid; she shall not harm thee, Helena.

332.speaker: DEMETRIUS.

207.speaker: BOTTOM.
207.line: [_Waking._] When my cue comes, call me, and I will answer. My next is

208.speaker: BOTTOM.
208.line: ‘Most fair Pyramus.’ Heigh-ho! Peter Quince! Flute, the bellows-mender!

209.speaker: BOTTOM.

210.speaker: BOTTOM.
210.line: asleep! I have had a most rare vision. I have had a dream, past the wit

211.speaker: BOTTOM.
211.line: of man to say what dream it was. Man is but an ass if he go about to

212.speaker: BOTTOM.
212.line: expound this dream. Methought I was—there is no man can tell what.

213.speaker: BOTTOM.
213.line: Methought I was, and methought I had—but man is but a patched fool if

214.speaker: BOTTOM.

215.speaker: BOTTOM.

216.speaker: BOTTOM.
216.line: his tongue to conceive, nor his heart to report, what my dream was. I

217.speaker: BOTTOM.

218.speaker: BOTTOM.
218.line: called ‘Bottom’s Dream’, because it hath no bottom; and I will sing it

219.speaker: BOTTOM.
219.line: in the latter end of a play, before the Duke. Peradventure, to make it

220.speaker: BOTTOM.
